latest news.eng_title: Why everyone is suddenly worried about Mexico's democracy
latest news.summary: Mexican President Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador is pushing for a constitutional amendment that would allow voters to elect nearly all federal judges, including those on the supreme court. Critics warn that this could undermine Mexico's young democracy and damage its economic partnership with the United States. The reform, which has been approved by the lower house of Congress, would require judges to resign in the next three years and be replaced by elected officials. This could lead to judges being influenced by popular support and potentially being sympathetic to the ruling party, Morena. López Obrador says elected judges will be more accountable to the population, but legal scholars and human-rights groups argue that the direct election of judges won't address the root of the problem: underfunding, inadequate training, and corruption. 'The judiciary has been kidnapped, and is at the service of a minority' -- the wealthy, López Obrador said in June. 'Elected judges will be more accountable to the population.'
latest news.title: Why everyone is suddenly worried about Mexico's democracy

latest news.eng_title: Claudia Sheinbaum: Proposed Changes Do Not Affect Investment or Trade
latest news.summary: Claudia Sheinbaum, the elected president of Mexico, stated that the proposed changes do not affect commercial relations or private national and foreign investments: 'On the contrary, there will be more and better rule of law and more democracy for all,' she said. She emphasized that democracy is the power of the people, citing Abraham Lincoln's definition: 'Democracy is the government of the people, by the people, and for the people.' Sheinbaum questioned the existence of authoritarianism, asking 'If the people elect the president, the Legislative Power, the judges, magistrates, and ministers, where is the authoritarianism?'
latest news.title: Claudia Sheinbaum: 'Cambios no afectan inversión ni comercio'

latest news.eng_title: Sheinbaum Denies Reform to Judicial Power Affects Commercial Relationships
latest news.summary: Claudia Sheinbaum, the elected president of Mexico, denied that the reform to the Judicial Power would affect the country's commercial relationships. She stated, 'The reform to the Judicial Power does not affect our commercial relationships, nor national or foreign private investments. On the contrary, there will be more and better Rule of Law and more democracy for all.' Sheinbaum emphasized that the reform is a popular mandate, following the June 2nd elections. She called for the release of the minutes from the Commission of Constitutional Points of the Chamber of Deputies on the constitutional reform to the Judicial Power. The US Ambassador to Mexico, Ken Salazar, warned that if the reform is not done well, it could damage the relationship between the two countries. He stated, 'If it's not done well, it can bring a lot of damage to the relationship. I'm not saying this just as an ambassador, I'm saying it because of all the concerns I'm receiving from people who truly want the best for Mexico and the United States.'
latest news.title: Niega Sheinbaum que reforma afecte relaciones comerciales

latest news.eng_title: González will not leave Venezuela despite arrest warrant, says lawyer
latest news.summary: Edmundo González, the main opposition candidate to Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro, will not leave the country despite a warrant for his arrest, according to his lawyer, José Vicente Haro. Haro stated, 'That scenario [González leaving Venezuela or seeking asylum] is not being planned or contemplated [...] His greatest desire is to be close to the Venezuelans and repay the support they have given him.' The warrant was condemned by 8 Latin American countries in a joint statement, including Argentina, Costa Rica, Guatemala, Paraguay, Peru, Dominican Republic, and Uruguay. Brazil and Colombia expressed 'deep concern', while the United States, which attributes the victory to González, condemned what they called 'persecution' against the opposition leader. González has been accused of usurpation of functions, falsification of public documents, incitement to disobedience of Venezuelan laws, computer crimes, and association with a criminal organization and conspiracy. He has been hiding since July 30, 2024, after a protest where he was present, demanding recognition of his victory in the presidential election. The Venezuelan Justice system has been accused of human rights abuses, including 'crimes of a political nature' and restrictions on freedom of the press. The election results have been contested by the international community, with the European Union and several countries, including the United States, Mexico, Argentina, Costa Rica, Chile, Ecuador, Guatemala, Panama, Paraguay, Peru, Dominican Republic, and Uruguay, refusing to recognize Maduro's victory.
latest news.title: González não deixará Venezuela apesar do mandado de prisão, diz defesa

latest news.eng_title: Comando con Vzla Condemns Arrest Warrant Against Edmundo González as 'Illegal and Immoral'
latest news.summary: The organization Comando con Vzla strongly rejected the arrest warrant issued against Edmundo González, a former presidential candidate, calling it 'illegal, unconstitutional, and immoral.' They stated that this action is an attempt to undermine the will of the people, which was clearly expressed in the elections. Comando con Vzla emphasized that even those who did not vote for González want a country where democracy and freedom prevail. They claimed that this act represents a 'red line' crossed by the government, but that it will not deter the determination of the Venezuelan people to seek peaceful and constitutional change. 'Nothing they do can hide the truth. On July 28, the people of Venezuela, honest and brave, raised their voice for peace and freedom. They did so without distinction of political color and overcoming all the barriers imposed on them,' they said. The group also stated that the international community has supported the opposition forces. 'We are all united in fighting for truth, justice, liberty, and the Republic... Liberty is our right and we will not give it up,' they concluded. The arrest warrant was issued on September 2, 2024, at the request of prosecutor Luis Ernesto Dueñez Reyes, accusing González of various crimes, including usurpation of functions, forgery of public documents, instigation of disobedience of laws, conspiracy, and sabotage.
latest news.title: ▷ Comando con Vzla calificó de ilegal e inconstitucional la orden de aprehensión contra Edmundo González

latest news.eng_title: Prosecutor's Office Investigates Incident of People Found Tied to Streetlights
latest news.summary: The West Zone Prosecutor's Office, led by Silvia González, has initiated an investigation after receiving reports that seven people were found tied to streetlights in San Juanito. According to González, the incident was reported to emergency numbers and, based on a case file, police officers from the Ministerial Police were dispatched to the area to verify the situation. However, upon arrival, the agents did not find the people tied up or the cards that were allegedly placed on their bodies. They only found the yellow tape used to tie the people. González stated that, despite the absence of the victims, the Prosecutor's Office has opened a case file for the crime of deprivation of liberty or any other crime that may be applicable. González explained that various actions are being taken to clarify the facts, including reviewing security cameras in the area and interviewing local residents. Additionally, she mentioned that access has been requested to the Centinela platform's videos to obtain more information about the incident. So far, González said that no reports of injured, hospitalized, or deceased people have been received in the region, nor have any previous complaints been filed for deprivation of liberty or disappearance of people in the area.
latest news.title: Nosotros no encontramos nada: Fiscalía Occidente tras hombres amarrados

latest news.eng_title: Concerns over Property Rights Reform in Mexico City: Jorge Sepúlveda

Organization: Consejo Nacional de la Barra Mexicana Colegio de Abogados

latest news.summary: Jorge Sepúlveda, a lawyer and member of the Consejo Nacional de la Barra Mexicana Colegio de Abogados, expressed concern over the recent decree on property rights in Mexico City. He stated, 'It's something to be worried about, I don't think it's a coincidence that they published this, considering the article they're reforming in the Constitution of Mexico City, which refers to the principles of the Constitution.' Sepúlveda warned that the reform is 'incendiary' and that the combination of the decree and the current state of the Poder Judicial is 'terrible.' He also stated that the reform would abolish the amparo institution, which was created to protect people from authority. Sepúlveda further warned that the Instituto Nacional Electoral (INE) and the Tribunal giving majority power to the ruling party in the government would allow them to eliminate property rights when they want. He said, 'Yes, in the context of everything that's happening... today, not yet, without the Poder Judicial, of course, yes... they're again hitting at trust, affecting investments.'
latest news.title: Preocupa propiedad privada por la reforma al Poder Judicial: Jorge Sepúlveda

latest news.eng_title: Venezuela Arrest Warrant for Presidential Candidate Edmundo Gonzalez Sparks International Outcry
latest news.summary: A warrant for the arrest of Edmundo Gonzalez, a former diplomat and presidential candidate in Venezuela's July 28, 2024 election, was published on the Venezuelan Attorney General's Instagram account on September 2, 2024. Gonzalez is accused of six crimes, including forgery, incitement to disobedience, conspiracy, electoral sabotage, and association to commit a crime. He faces over 20 years in prison. More than 1700 people, including opposition leaders like Biagio Pilieri, have been arrested following protests after the National Electoral Council announced that Nicolas Maduro had won his third presidential term. The opposition claims that Pilieri is being held at the Helicoïde prison, a former shopping mall turned torture center by Venezuelan security forces. Nine Latin American countries have rejected the arrest warrant, stating that it is 'a new attempt to silence Mr. González, ignore the Venezuelan people's will, and constitute a political persecution.' The whereabouts of Gonzalez and Maria Corina Machado, another opposition leader, are unknown as they have gone into hiding. Meanwhile, Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro has declared that Christmas celebrations will begin on October 1, 2024.
latest news.title: Au Venezuela, Edmundo Gonzalez, candidat présidentiel visé par un mandat d'arrêt

latest news.eng_title: Argentina, Costa Rica, and Peru Condemn Venezuelan Order to Arrest Edmundo González Urrutia
latest news.summary: The governments of Argentina, Costa Rica, Guatemala, Paraguay, Peru, Dominican Republic, and Uruguay have jointly condemned the Venezuelan justice's order to arrest Edmundo González Urrutia for 'delitos asociados al terrorismo' (crimes associated with terrorism). According to the statement, 'This arrest order cites several supposed crimes that are nothing more than another attempt to silence Mr. González, ignore the Venezuelan people's will, and constitute political persecution.' The governments 'condemn these dictatorial practices and our efforts will be firm and continuous to demand that Venezuelan authorities guarantee the life, integrity, and freedom of Edmundo González Urrutia.' They also reject 'any attempt to curtail the fundamental rights' of the Venezuelan opposition candidate. Spain has also defended González Urrutia's freedom of expression and manifestation, and has rejected any attempt to curtail his fundamental rights.
latest news.title: Argentina, Costa Rica, Perú y otros rechazan orden contra EGU: "Condenamos prácticas dictatoriales"

latest news.eng_title: Concerns over high number of cases of illegal deprivation of liberty in Ensenada

Organization: Comité Ciudadano de Seguridad Pública de Ensenada

latest news.summary: The president of the Comité Ciudadano de Seguridad Pública de Ensenada, Edgar Hernández González, expressed concern over the high number of cases of illegal deprivation of liberty in the city, with 61 cases reported in the first seven months of the year. He noted that the type of crime is also a concern, as it often involves people being taken without a clear reason, and sometimes without any ransom being demanded. The Fiscalía General del Estado has issued 20 search warrants for missing persons in the past two weeks, with six people found and one found dead. The activist and researcher Adriana Jaén Manuel from the organization 'Elementa Derechos Humanos' stated that the authorities are not taking the issue seriously and are not providing clear information about the number of missing persons. She also mentioned that the organization has been trying to get information from the Fiscalía General del Estado, but they have been denied, citing confidentiality. The organization plans to file a review of the decision. 'We cannot say we are going to solve the problem of disappearances if we do not even have clarity on who we are looking for, who these people are, in what municipalities they are, how they are, etc.', she said. 'The law of transparency and access to public information is very clear in its article five and refers that no information in which there has been a grave violation of a human right can be classified, that is another problem', she added.
latest news.title: Van 61 casos de privación ilegal de la libertad en Ensenada: CCSP

news knowledge.eng_title: Edmundo González Urrutia Faces Contempt of Court Charges
news knowledge.summary: Edmundo González Urrutia, a Venezuelan politician, has been involved in a case of contempt of court after failing to appear before the Electoral Chamber of the Supreme Court of Justice (TSJ) as required by a citation. González Urrutia justified his absence on social media, claiming that his freedom and the will of the Venezuelan people were at risk. According to Cecilia Sosa Gómez, González Urrutia's actions constitute a contempt of authority, as defined by Article 483 of the Penal Code, which carries penalties such as arrest or fine. The Electoral Chamber has ordered the Public Ministry to investigate alleged crimes related to usurpation of functions, forgery of public documents, instigation to disobey the law, computer crimes, association to commit a crime, and conspiracy. González Urrutia has been cited three times as an investigated person, and if he fails to appear, an arrest warrant will be issued. This situation highlights that contempt of court citations can result in the deprivation of liberty while the investigation is ongoing.
news knowledge.title: ¿A qué se expone Edmundo González ante la justicia?

news knowledge.eng_title: Edmundo González Urrutia Faces Third Summons and Possible Arrest
news knowledge.summary: Edmundo González Urrutia, the leader of the opposition and the Plataforma Unitaria Democrática, is facing a third summons from the Public Ministry in an investigation into the electoral results. If González does not attend this new summons, the consequences could be severe, as the Prosecutor's Office has warned that, if he does not present himself, an arrest warrant will be issued against him. The summons, scheduled for this Friday, is part of a series of legal actions that seek to investigate the accusations made by the presidential candidate, who claimed to have collected 83.5% of the electoral acts to demonstrate a supposed fraud in the presidential elections of July 28. These acts, published by the Plataforma Unitaria and qualified as 'false' by the government of Nicolás Maduro, has led the Public Ministry to investigate the alleged commission of several crimes, including usurpation of functions, forgery of a public document, and association for delinquency. The Chavist Attorney General, Tarek William Saab, explained that, according to Venezuelan jurisprudence, it is allowed to summon a person up to three times before taking more severe measures. Given González Urrutia's refusal to attend the first two summonses, the Prosecutor's Office prepared the third and last summons, clearly stating that the absence could trigger his arrest. In this context, the Venezuelan diplomat could face not only the deprivation of his liberty, but also an irregular judicial process, as has happened with the political prisoners of the Chavist government. Additionally, the risk of flight pointed out by the Prosecutor's Office could be used to justify more stringent precautionary measures, complicating the situation of the opposition leader even further. As Tarek William Saab said, 'According to Venezuelan jurisprudence, we allow summoning a person up to three times before taking more severe measures.'
news knowledge.title: ¿Qué enfrenta Edmundo González si no acude a tercera citación?

news knowledge.eng_title: Edmundo González Rejects Supreme Court Decision Confirming Maduro's Victory
news knowledge.summary: Edmundo González, the leader of the Venezuelan opposition coalition Plataforma Unitaria Democrática (PUD), rejected the decision of the Supreme Court of Justice (TSJ) on Thursday, August 22, 2024, which confirmed the victory of Nicolás Maduro in the presidential elections. According to González, 'the sovereignty resides intransferiblemente in the people', as stated in the Constitution. The TSJ validated the election results at the request of Maduro, who filed a lawsuit that was never known and for which the 10 former presidential candidates were summoned. However, González declined to attend, considering that the verification is not the competence of the TSJ, but rather the National Electoral Council (CNE). González warned that the decision of the Supreme Court 'will only aggravate the crisis' in the country, which is already experiencing a crisis after the disputed victory of Maduro. He also stated that the Venezuelans are not willing to 'renounce' their 'liberty' or their 'right to change peacefully to live better' after the presidential elections. The PUD considers that González obtained the victory, according to the '83.5% of the acts' that they claim to have collected through witnesses and members of the electoral table, documents that the government considers 'false'.
news knowledge.title: Edmundo González rechaza el fallo del Supremo que confirma la victoria electoral

news knowledge.eng_title: Venezuela: Edmundo González rejects TSJ summons to certify election results
news knowledge.summary: Edmundo González Urrutia, the leader of the Venezuelan opposition, has rejected the summons to the Supreme Court of Justice (TSJ) to certify the results of the presidential elections, considering it a 'violation of due process' and not corresponding to any procedure in Venezuelan law. According to González Urrutia, if he were to attend the Electoral Chamber, he would do so in a situation of 'absolute defenselessness' because the procedure followed by the Electoral Chamber does not correspond to any legal procedure in the Organic Law of the TSJ and another law on electoral jurisdiction. González Urrutia stated that the Electoral Chamber cannot 'usurp' the constitutional functions of the National Electoral Council (CNE) and 'certify' results that have not been produced in accordance with the Constitution and the law, with access to the original acts that serve as the basis for a totalization and proclamation, and with the necessary audits. González Urrutia warned that if he attends the TSJ, he will be in 'absolute vulnerability due to defenselessness and violation of due process' and will put his liberty and the 'will of the Venezuelan people expressed on July 28, 2024' at risk. He also called on the authorities to 'recover their sanity and seek dialogue in a frank and acceptable framework that safeguards human rights'.
news knowledge.title: Venezuela: Edmundo González rechaza acudir a la citación del Tribunal Supremo de Justicia, manejado por Maduro

news knowledge.eng_title: Edmundo González Refuses to Attend Hearing at Venezuelan Supreme Court

Organization: Supreme Court of Justice of Venezuela
Title: President of Venezuela

news knowledge.summary: Edmundo González, a Venezuelan opposition leader, has stated that he will not attend a hearing at the Supreme Court of Justice of Venezuela, citing that he would be putting his liberty at risk and questioning the legitimacy of the proceedings. González claims that the process initiated by the Electoral Chamber of the Supreme Court does not correspond to any legal procedure. He also stated that the President of Venezuela, Nicolás Maduro, has publicly warned that if he does not attend, he will incur in legal responsibilities, and if he does attend and submits copies of the electoral acts, he will also face serious penal consequences. González emphasized that he would be in a situation of absolute vulnerability and would put at risk not only his liberty but also the will of the Venezuelan people expressed on July 28, 2024. He called on the authorities to recover their senses and seek a dialogue to resolve the matter in a constitutional and acceptable manner, respecting human rights and the sovereignty of the people.
news knowledge.title: Dice que arriesgaría su libertad: Edmundo González descarta comparecer ante Tribunal Supremo de Justicia de Venezuela

news knowledge.eng_title: Campaign Chief of Edmundo González Detained in Monagas
news knowledge.summary: Ángel Aristimuño, the campaign chief of Edmundo González in Monagas, was detained by government security officials on Saturday. The detention was recorded in a video shared by opposition leader María Gabriela Hernández, according to El Nacional. In the video, some associates ask about the arrest warrant and one of the operatives says it has a date of July 8. This incident is part of the irregular situations that have been reported against several members of Edmundo González and María Corina Machado's team. Hernández condemned the situation, calling it a new attack on the opposition. She tweeted, 'The campaign chief of Edmundo González and president of the party Un Nuevo Tiempo in Monagas, Ángel Aristimuño, was deprived of his liberty by Judge Erick Ferrer's order. Each repressive action by the regime digs him deeper into electoral defeat, which we Venezuelans have already inflicted on him.' Additionally, María Oropeza, coordinator of Vente Venezuela in Portuguesa, reported that Mary Rodríguez, the campaign director of the Capital Guanare parish, and Mayra Montilla, also from the team, were detained and their home was arbitrarily searched by DGCIM, PNB, state police, and GNB.
news knowledge.title: Detuvieron al jefe del comando de campaña de Edmundo González en Monagas

news knowledge.eng_title: Edmundo González Urrutia's Daughter Did Not Serve Time in Prison or Commit Serious Crimes
news knowledge.summary: A viral file claimed that Edmundo González Urrutia's daughter served time in prison for committing several crimes, including unlawful deprivation of liberty and bribery. However, an investigation by The Carabobeño Detects found that the woman mentioned in the file, Erika Carolina González Urrutia, is not the daughter of Edmundo González Urrutia. The investigation also found that the ID number provided in the file does not match any of Edmundo González Urrutia's daughters. The daughters of Edmundo González Urrutia have the first surname of their father and mother, Gonzalez Lopez.
news knowledge.title: Edmundo González Urrutia's daughter did not serve time in prison or commit 'serious crimes'

news knowledge.eng_title: Detention of Ángel Aristimuño, Campaign Chief of Edmundo González in Monagas
news knowledge.summary: Ángel Aristimuño, the campaign chief of Edmundo González in Monagas, was detained by government security officials on Saturday. The detention was recorded in a video published by opposition leader María Gabriela Hernández, which shows officials discussing the capture order and one of them mentioning a date of July 8. This incident is part of a series of irregular situations against several members of Edmundo González and María Corina Machado's team. Hernández condemned the situation, calling it a new attack on the opposition. In a post on X, she said: 'The campaign chief of Edmundo González and president of the Un Nuevo Tiempo party in Monagas, Ángel Aristimuño, was deprived of his liberty by Judge Erick Ferrer's order. Each repressive action by the regime digs it deeper into electoral defeat, which we Venezuelans have already inflicted upon them.' Additionally, María Oropeza, coordinator of Vente Venezuela in Portuguesa, reported that Mary Rodríguez, the campaign director of the Capital Guanare parish, and Mayra Montilla were detained and their home was arbitrarily searched by Dgcim, PNB, state police, and GNB. The journalist, Mario Hurtado, who tried to cover the incident, was mistreated by officials and had his photo chip removed. Oropeza stated that this is how the regime acts during an election campaign, treating those who only want freedom as criminals.
news knowledge.title: Detuvieron a Ángel Aristimuño, jefe de comando de campaña de Edmundo González en Monagas

news knowledge.eng_title: False Claim: Edmundo González Urrutia's Daughter Did Not Commit Crimes
news knowledge.summary: A viral document claims that Edmundo González Urrutia's daughter was imprisoned for committing several crimes, including illegal deprivation of liberty, intentional personal injuries, and corruption. However, an investigation by El Carabobeño DetECta found that the woman mentioned in the document, Érika Carolina González Urrutia, is not the daughter of the presidential candidate. The investigation found that the woman's name and ID number match those of a different person, and that the candidate's daughters have the first name González López, not González Urrutia.
news knowledge.title: Hija de Edmundo González Urrutia no pagó prisión ni cometió «graves delitos»

news knowledge.eng_title: Edmundo González Calls for Mass Vote to Bring About Change in Venezuela
news knowledge.summary: Edmundo González, a presidential candidate for the Plataforma Unitaria, urged opposition supporters to organize and vote en masse on July 28 to bring about a political change in the country. He mentioned the collapse of public services, including permanent power outages, gasoline shortages, and the state of public education. González also promised to reunify families and change the government. The event was attended by María Corina Machado and other opposition leaders. The crowd chanted 'liberty', 'yes we can', and 'this government will fall'. Machado stated that they are only 22 days away from their freedom and that they have already defeated the tyranny. Over 53,000 'comanditos' are active to defend popular sovereignty. The event was also attended by Freddy Superlano, leader of Voluntad Popular, who said that Barinas has started the change in Venezuela.
news knowledge.title: Edmundo González desde Barinas: Si salimos todos el 28 de julio el cambio es indetenible
